definitions.definition: the most important quality or feature of something, that makes it what it is

examples.text: His paintings capture the essence of France.
In essence *(= when you consider the most important points)*, your situation isn't so different from mine.
His paintings embody the very essence of the immediate post-war years.
His theory was not new in essence.
His work misses the essence of what Eastern religion is about.
The freedom to pick your leaders is the essence of a democracy.
The girl has her own spiritual essence.
They distilled the essence of their message into three principles.
Like so many peasant foods, the essence of pasta is its simplicity.

definitions.definition: a liquid taken from a plant, etc. that contains its smell and taste in a very strong form

examples.text: In this situation **time is of the essence** *(= we must do things as quickly as possible)*.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin essentia, from esse ‘be’.
